title: Susten Pass: The supersized Swiss climb

Susten Pass: The supersized Swiss climb

Did you know that until just a few years ago, much of Switzerland’s major infrastructure – bridges, tunnels, roads and so forth – was packed with explosives, ready to be detonated when invasion threatened? The practice was a hangover from the Cold War, a time when irritable superpowers menaced one another with complete annihilation. How times change.

There’s a tortured analogy in here somewhere about a road’s hidden dangers, or perhaps something about blowing up when it all gets to be too much on a tough climb, but like every major tourist route in Switzerland, the Susten Pass is beguilingly perfect and largely free of jeopardy – legions of cars and motorbikes notwithstanding.

Supposedly the TNT has now been removed, but in any case, the Swiss are the one nationality I’d trust to leave bombs everywhere safely. No matter how extreme the scenery, riding here always gives you the feeling you’re in good hands. You are going to do battle with the supersized landscape, not the infrastructure, which is unrelentingly perfect at all times.

The western front

The heir to a 17th century mule track, the modern day Susten Pass road was built from 1938 to 1945, and inaugurated in 1946. It links the towns of Innertkirchen in the Bernese Oberland on the western side to Wassen in the canton of Uri on the eastern side. This is the western approach, which tops out at 2,224m above sea level.

The Susten isn’t really an essential transport link for anyone because there are more practical routes if you really need to get somewhere. Most of the traffic here is from tourism, so it’s one of the last passes to open for the high season as the snow recedes. It’s usually ridable from some point in June, closing in October or even early November.

Consistent excellence

The Susten does and does not offer variety. Visually it’s uniformly pleasing, but it takes time to really get going before it transitions from merely pretty to truly, breathtakingly stunning. Roughly the whole of the first half is an unthreatening Alpine meander, a succession of cute but orderly villages dotted along a valley, with picturesque meadows and densely forested hillsides for company.

Switzerland does rustic particularly well, but it’s never shabby. The odd bit of weathered wood on a chalet is more like the patina on a piece of antique furniture than actual evidence of decay. One has the sense this is a country that lives comfortably in amongst its heritage rather than treating it as something to be preserved in glass cases. This is no theme park, it’s just a place that has chosen not to change because the way things are done here is precisely tailored to the landscape and the seasons.

This is evident when you examine early photos of the road itself. Hardly a bollard has moved in over 70 years and the aesthetics haven’t been cheapened with plastic road furniture, or Armco for that matter. Many of the drops further up the climb remain impressively perilous, and there are no second chances when it comes to riding back down.

While no part of the pass is ultra-steep, some of the more challenging sections arrive early on, but even these just barely flirt with double-digit percentages. It’s fair to say things get more interesting in the second half of the climb. The views open up considerably and the road embarks on a furious series of wiggles that affords an endless variety of thrilling backdrops, and plenty of opportunities to get out of the saddle as you power round a hairpin. What is it that’s so addictive about a 180° bend in a road? It’s probably the brief illusion of rapid progress after a long, steady grind, and there’s a whole lot of that on the Susten.

There are also short tunnels at intervals along the pass, which on a bright day will plunge you into the inkiest of blackness. It’s well worth having a good rear light for these because motorists can be caught unawares by the sudden transitions.

The tunnels are a signature of the Susten, located where it was deemed easier to punch through immense rocky outcrops than trying to skirt around them. A waterfall cascades lazily over one of the more striking of these, brave rock climbers dangling in its spray.

The upper part of the climb looks out towards the Stein glacier, a magnificent duvet of ice draped over the mountain. Its retreat has created a sizable lake that, while beautiful, is an ominous sign of the times. It’s hard to ignore the obvious evidence of how much bigger the glacier must have been, even in living memory.

The final pair of hairpins delivers you to a finish that’s almost anticlimactic after such wonders along the way. There’s the obligatory mountain restaurant to cater to all your rösti requirements, the usual gaggle of tourists and bikers high on mountain air.

A small lake (or large pond) offers pleasing reflections of the surrounding peaks, while the road disappears into another tunnel to begin the descent of the eastern side towards Wassen.

Susten-ability

While the Susten is, by any reasonable measure, an immense climb, it’s not actually all that difficult. The gradients are steady and rarely truly testing, so it offers a tremendous return on the investment of your effort.

With appropriate gearing – a typical road compact setup will suffice – and an understanding that you’re in it for the long haul, it’s a climb within reach of most.

If there’s a downside to the Susten it’s that it’s a victim of its own popularity. Countless car and motorcycle publications laud it as one of the best Alpine passes for driving and riding thrills. Combined with the limited opening, it can be busy when the weather is good. Don’t let this put you off, however, because the views are second to none and, with well-sighted corners and immaculate surfaces, negotiating the traffic is rarely stressful.

Disliking things because they’re popular is self-defeating, and the Susten deserves its place in the Alpine pass hall of fame. It’s also very unlikely to explode.
